Literature Review: Insulin clearance plays a crucial role in maintaining normal glucose homeostasis. The process involves the binding of insulin to its receptor, followed by receptor-mediated endocytosis and degradation, primarily in the liver (hepatocytes) and to a lesser extent in extrahepatic peripheral tissues. Impaired insulin clearance has been implicated in various diseases, including insulin resistance, obesity, hepatic steatosis, and type 2 diabetes. This review aims to summarize the evidence suggesting a pathogenic role for reduced insulin clearance in these conditions.
